text: This is totally dumb but totally amusing to look back on (published in 2008). An article claiming Apple was being misogynistic and alienating 30% of their demographic [the estimated amount of women using the device] for making their touch screens too difficult to use with long nails: <http://www.businessinsider.com.au/apple-iphone-discriminates-against-women-and-fat-people-2008-5>

attachments.title: Apple iPhone Design Alienates Women and Large People
attachments.text: Only one-third of Apple iPhone buyers are women. This is an improvement over the old ratio–one-fourth–but it’s still nothing to be proud of. Why are women avoiding the device? Because it’s hard to use with long fingernails. DailyTech:
attachments.fallback: Business Insider Australia: Apple iPhone Design Alienates Women and Large People

text: Im not sure BI has ever written a non-stupid article on Apple. Seriously - it's sort of amazing how uniformly their reporting on Apple has maintained a "smart first grader" level of intellect.

the real competition was here all along. Get ready for the final tomorrow! <http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_spot/2014/07/03/world_cup_player_introductions_a_deep_analysis_of_how_soccer_players_fold.html>

attachments.title: Who Won the World Cup of Arm-Folding?
attachments.text: This year’s World Cup has featured some of the planet's greatest athletes performing seemingly impossible physical tasks. Bicycle kicks. Spectacular goals. Mind-bending saves. Displays of endurance, determination, and balletic grace. And, of course, turning to the left and folding your arms. It turns out that's surprisingly hard to ace on...
attachments.fallback: Slate Magazine: Who Won the World Cup of Arm-Folding?

text: (considering how bad my day is going, it wouldn't have taken much, but even on a good day, this would have stood out)
